wp:Content.noNote: NOTE To enable the Cap Bank Control features of Yukon, you must purchase the Cap Control module. For more information about this module, contact a Cannon Technologies sales representative.
wp:Content.boBody: Web based capacitor control allows you to access your capacitor control system without having to install a software client on your computer.
To access the Web based capacitor control client:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Start Internet Explorer and enter the address of the Yukon Web server.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Enter a username and password that has privileges to access the Web based capacitor control client.
Click Submit to log into the Web based capacitor control client.
wp:Content.boBody: The first page that appears after logging in is the Substation Bus Areas page, which displays information about the substation bus areas defined in the system.

The Substation Bus Areas page displays the following information:
Table 1.1 Substation Bus Area Information
Column
Meaning
Area Name
Name of the geographical area of the substation bus.
State
Operational status of the substation bus area.
Setup
Number of substations with the substation area.
Closed kVARs
kVAr reading of closed capacitor banks.
Tripped kVARs
kVAr reading of tripped capacitor banks.
PFactor / Est.
PFactor is the current power factor on the substation bus.
Est. is an estimate of what the power factor would be if no cap banks were closed.

If you click the + next to the name of a substation bus area (e.g. Southern Area), the substation bus(es) within a substation bus area are displayed. In addition, the number of feeders and capacitor banks assigned to each substation bus are displayed.
System commands can be sent to the Yukon server by placing the mouse cursor over the State value and selecting one of the following commands:
wp:Content.sbuStepBullet: Confirm Area - confirms the status of the selected substation bus area.
Disable Area/Enable Area - disables or enables the selected substation bus area.
wp:Content.boBody: To display detailed information about the substation bus(es) within a substation bus area, click on the name of the substation bus area (e.g. Southern Area) to display the Substation Buses In Area page.

The Substation Buses In Area page displays the following information:
Table 1.2 Substation Bus Information
Column
Meaning
Sub Name
Name of the substation bus. If a (V) appear next to the name, this means that the substation bus is currently being used in a verification schedule.
State
Operational status of the substation bus.
Target
If the control algorithm is kVAr, this is the target VAr range.
If the control algorithm is Power Factor, this is the target power factor.
If the control algorithm is Multi Volt, Volts, or Multi Volt VAr, this is the target voltage range.
VAr Load / Est.
VAr Load is the current VAr value on the substation bus. Est. is an estimate of what the VAr Load would be if no cap banks were on (closed).
Date/Time
Date and time of the last substation bus data received.
PFactor / Est.
PFactor is the current power factor on the substation bus.
Est. is an estimate of what the power factor would be if no cap banks were on (closed).
Watts/Volts
Watts displays the wattage reading of the substation bus.
Volts displays the voltage reading of the substation bus.
Daily / Max Ops
Daily is the daily total operation count for all of the cap banks on the substation bus.
Max Ops is a user-defined maximum number of cap bank operations.
System commands can be sent to the Yukon server by placing the mouse cursor over the State value and selecting one of the following commands:
wp:Content.sbuStepBullet: Confirm Sub - confirms the status of the selected substation bus.
Disable Sub/Enable Sub - disables or enables the selected substation bus.
Reset Op Counts - resets the operation count to zero for the cap banks on the selected substation bus.
Verify All Banks - verifies the status of all cap banks on the selected substation bus.
Verify Failed and Questionable Banks - verifies the status of all failed and questionable cap banks on the selected substation bus.
Verify Failed Banks - verifies the status of all failed cap banks on the selected substation bus.
Verify Questionable Banks - verifies the status of questionable cap banks on the selected substation bus.
wp:Content.boBody: If a manual verification or a scheduled verification is running, the following command appears in the commands list:
wp:Content.sbuStepBullet: Verify Stop - stops the verification of cap banks on the selected substation bus.
wp:Content.h1Heading1: 1.4. Substation Bus, Feeders, and Capacitor Banks
wp:Content.boBody: To display detailed information about the feeders and capacitor banks assigned to a substation bus, click on the name of a substation bus.
To view additional information about the selected substation bus, click the + next to the name of the substation bus.

The following information is displayed:
Table 1.3 Substation Bus Information
Column
Meaning
Area
Name of the geographical area of the substation bus.
Control Method
Type of control and control algorithm for the substation bus.
VAr Point
VAr point on the cap control system assigned to the substation bus.
Watt Point
Watt point on the cap control system assigned to the substation bus.
Volt Point
Voltage point on the cap control system assigned to the substation bus.

The following information is displayed about feeders:
Table 1.4 Feeder Information
Column
Meaning
Feeder Name
Name for the feeder.
State
Operational status of the feeder.
Target
If the control algorithm is kVAr, this is the target VAr range.
If the control algorithm is Power Factor, this is the target power factor.
If the control algorithm is Multi Volt, Volts, or Multi Volt VAr, this is the target voltage range.
VAr Load / Est.
VAr Load is the current VAr value on the feeder.
Est. is an estimate of what the VAr Load would be if no cap banks were closed.
Date/Time
Date and time of the last feeder data received.
PFactor / Est.
PFactor is the current power factor on the feeder.
Est. is an estimate of what the power factor would be if no cap banks were closed.
Watts/Volts
Watts and voltage reading of the feeder.
Daily / Max Ops
Daily total operation count and maximum allowed operation count for all of the cap banks on the feeder.
wp:Content.i1Indent1: System commands can be sent to the Yukon server by placing the mouse cursor over the State value and selecting one of the following commands:
wp:Content.sbuStepBullet: Disable Feeder/Enable Feeder - disables or enables the selected feeder.
Reset Op Counts - resets the operation count to zero for the cap banks on the selected feeder.
wp:Content.boBody:
The following information is displayed about cap banks:
Table 1.5 Cap Bank Information
Column
Meaning
CB Name (Order)
Name for the cap bank and the order the cap banks are closed/opened.
State
Operational status of the cap bank.
Bank Address
Geographical location or street address of the cap bank.
Date/Time
Date and time of the last cap bank data received.
Bank Size
Size of the cap bank in kVAr.
Parent Feeder
Feeder to which the capacitor bank is assigned. The cap banks on all of the feeders are displayed by default. To display the cap banks on a single feeder, select the feeder from the drop-down list.
Op Count
Total operation count for the cap bank.
To temporarily move a cap bank from its parent feeder to another feeder:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Click on the name of the cap bank's current parent feeder to move the cap bank.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Click the + next to a substation bus to display the feeders assigned to the sub bus.
Enter a new control order for the cap bank in the New Control Order text box.
Click on the name of a feeder to temporarily move the cap bank to that feeder.
Click the Close button to close the Cap Bank Temp Move window.
wp:Content.i1Indent1: After a cap bank has been temporarily moved, the parent feeder for that cap bank appears in orange text.
wp:Content.boBody: To move a cap bank back to its original parent feeder:
wp:Content.s1Step1:
Place the mouse cursor over the name of the parent feeder for the moved cap bank.
The parent feeder's name appears in orange text.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Click on the Temp Move Back link to move the cap bank back to its original parent feeder.
wp:Content.boBody: To send a field command to a cap bank, place the mouse cursor over the name of the cap bank and select one of the following commands:
wp:Content.buBullet: Confirm - confirms the status of the cap bank.

boBold.wp:style: display: inline; color: #000000; font-style: normal; font-weight: bold; text-decoration: none; text-transform: none; vertical-align: baseline

wp.wp:style: display: inline; color: #000000; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: none; text-transform: none; vertical-align: baseline

wp:Content.buBullet: Close Capacitor - closes the capacitor bank.
Enable OV/UV - enables Over Voltage/Under Voltage (OV/UV) detection of the capacitor bank.
Disable OV/UV - disables Over Voltage/Under Voltage (OV/UV) detection of the capacitor bank.
wp:Content.boBody: System commands can be sent to the Yukon server by placing the mouse cursor over the State value and selecting one of the following commands:
wp:Content.buBullet: Disable Cap Bank/Enable Cap Bank - disables or enables a cap bank.
Reset Op Counts - set the operation count to the value entered for the selected cap bank.
Open - sets the cap bank state to opened.
Close - sets the cap bank state to closed.
OpenQuestionable - sets the cap bank state to opened questionable.
CloseQuestionable - sets the cap bank state to closed questionable.
OpenFail - sets the cap bank state to opened failed.
CloseFail - sets the cap bank state to closed failed.
OpenPending - sets the cap bank state to opened pending.
ClosePending - sets the cap bank state to closed pending.
wp:Content.boBody: To reset the operation count of a Capacitor Bank:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Place the mouse cursor over the State value of a Cap Bank and select Reset Op Counts.
wp:Content.i1Indent1: An Op Count Value column appears to the right of the State column.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Enter a new operation count in the Op Count Value text box.

wp.wp:style: display: inline; color: #000000; font-style: italic; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: none; text-transform: none; vertical-align: baseline

i1Indent1.wp: If the Op Count Value text box is left blank, the operation count will be reset to zero.

wp:Content.s2Step2: Click Reset to set the operation count to the value in the Op Count Value text box.
wp:Content.boBody: The Web based capacitor control client allows you to view reports of capacitor control data.
To view a report of today's kVAr and Watt values:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Select up to three substation buses or feeders that have kVAr and Watt points.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Click Analysis.
Click Today kVAr/Watt to display the report.
wp:Content.boBody: To view a report of today's power factor values:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Select up to three substation buses or feeders that have power factor points.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Click Analysis.
Click Today PF to display the report.
wp:Content.boBody: To view a report of the past 30 day's kVAr and Watt values:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Select up to three substation buses or feeders that have kVAr and Watt points.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Click Analysis.
Click 30 Day kVAr/Watt to display the report.
wp:Content.boBody: To view a report of the past 30 day's power factor values:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Select up to three substation buses or feeders that have power factor points.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Click Analysis.
Click 30 Day PF to display the report.
wp:Content.boBody: The Web based capacitor control client allows you to view orphaned devices or devices that have not been assigned to parent devices.
To view feeders that have not been assigned to a substation bus, click View and then select Orphaned Feeders.
To view capacitor banks that have not been assigned to a feeder, click View and then select Orphaned CapBanks.
To view CBCs that have not been assigned to a capacitor bank, click View and then select Orphaned CBCs.

The Web based capacitor control client allows you to view schedules that can be assigned to substation buses to control when cap bank verification commands are sent.The following information is displayed about schedules:
Table 1.6 Cap Bank Information
Column
Meaning
Name
Name of the schedule.
Next Run Time
The date and time the schedule will run.
Last Run Time
The date and time the schedule last ran.
Interval
How often the schedule runs.
Disabled
Displays if the schedule is disabled from running.
(Edit)
To edit a schedule, click the (Edit) button.
Delete
To delete a schedule, click the Delete button.
To view a report of the recent controls:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Select one or more devices for which to view recent controls.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Click View.
Click Recent Controls to display the report.
wp:Content.boBody: To view a report of the recent cap bank moves:
wp:Content.s2Step2: Click Recent Cap Bank Moves to display the report.
